content.raw: is there a place in gui that knows it's about to exit so that we can shutdown the rendering engine and cleanup the objects?

content.raw: ya before the main window exits. Because the plugins come and go right? and they leave grids and scenes behind?
content.html: ya before the main window exits. Because the plugins come and go right? and they leave grids and scenes behind?

content.raw:
With the current implementation, the core of ign-gui is independent of rendering. I think it would be nice if we could keep it like that.

Don't things in rendering self-destruct once no one is using them anymore (smart-pointer-style)?
content.html:
With the current implementation, the core of ign-gui is independent of rendering. I think it would be nice if we could keep it like that.

Don't things in rendering self-destruct once no one is using them anymore (smart-pointer-style)?

content.raw: The `engine` keeps a list of `scenes` and destroys them when engine exists but unfortunately that requires an explicit `engine->Fini()` call as self-destructing an engine using smart-pointer-style can potentially be bad, e.g. if done in a different thread.
content.html: The engine keeps a list of scenes and destroys them when engine exists but unfortunately that requires an explicit engine->Fini() call as self-destructing an engine using smart-pointer-style can potentially be bad, e.g. if done in a different thread.

content.raw: maybe we need a separate plugin to listen to a main window event to shutdown rendering?
content.html: maybe we need a separate plugin to listen to a main window event to shutdown rendering?

content.raw: we can probably ticket this issue first as it maybe non-trivial to solve
content.html: we can probably ticket this issue first as it maybe non-trivial to solve

content.raw:
Ok I see what you're saying. Right now each `Scene3D` plugin creates a camera. How about destroying the camera when the plugin exits, and if that is the last camera we also bring down the engine?

I'm sure we will have other use cases where we want the scene to stay alive even without cameras, but I think we could handle this once it becomes an issue.
content.html:
Ok I see what you're saying. Right now each Scene3D plugin creates a camera. How about destroying the camera when the plugin exits, and if that is the last camera we also bring down the engine?

I'm sure we will have other use cases where we want the scene to stay alive even without cameras, but I think we could handle this once it becomes an issue.

content.raw: Correction: if that's the last camera on the scene, destroy the scene. If that's the last scene on the engine, destroy the engine.
content.html: Correction: if that's the last camera on the scene, destroy the scene. If that's the last scene on the engine, destroy the engine.

content.raw:
From 7eb4575 the camera and scene are being deleted. Then starting a new plugin will create a new scene:

![scenedestroy.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/64K5zaR/images/1170803137-scenedestroy.gif)

If I finish the engine, the program crashes when I try to create a new plugin. I think that's because of what you said - the engine should be finished only when the program is about to be closed.
content.html:
From 7eb4575 the camera and scene are being deleted. Then starting a new plugin will create a new scene:

If I finish the engine, the program crashes when I try to create a new plugin. I think that's because of what you said - the engine should be finished only when the program is about to be closed.

content.raw: could be but would be nice to see a backtrace to know what the problem is. I think for now, deleting the scene and camera is good enough.
content.html: could be but would be nice to see a backtrace to know what the problem is. I think for now, deleting the scene and camera is good enough.

content.html: I ticketed issue #17 about this, there's a backtrace there.

content.raw: The html output from doxygen merges all of this onto a single line. I think you'll need to use a markdown list for each configuration option.
content.html: The html output from doxygen merges all of this onto a single line. I think you'll need to use a markdown list for each configuration option.

content.raw: By markdown list do you mean using `*`? The list on [TimePanel](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/src/09e72dffee21e425ed3bfaf804c579c64a8166c7/include/ignition/gui/plugins/TimePanel.hh?fileviewer=file-view-default#TimePanel.hh-36) looks [indented, but without bullets](https://ignitionrobotics.org/api/gui/0.1/classignition_1_1gui_1_1plugins_1_1TimePanel.html#details). The header looks like it works as expected, I haven't looked into the code to check what exactly doxygen supports.
content.html: By markdown list do you mean using *? The list on TimePanel looks indented, but without bullets. The header looks like it works as expected, I haven't looked into the code to check what exactly doxygen supports.

content.raw: Yes, use the `*`. Lines 49-55 use the `*`, but the preceding lines do not and are merged in html.
content.html: Yes, use the *. Lines 49-55 use the *, but the preceding lines do not and are merged in html.

content.html: While fixing pull request #73, I learned that we can escape the < and > for doxygen to stop printing HTML-related warnings

content.html: I think the timepanel looks okay because there is only one element that is lacking a *.

content.raw: Not hard, we could give it an object name and reference it on `style.qss`. Another thing I've been looking into recently is styling based on properties, so we could give the button a property like "warning" and have a common style for all widgets which carry this property. This is coll because it can be programmatically manipulated. Should I go ahead and implement it?
content.html: Not hard, we could give it an object name and reference it on style.qss. Another thing I've been looking into recently is styling based on properties, so we could give the button a property like "warning" and have a common style for all widgets which carry this property. This is coll because it can be programmatically manipulated. Should I go ahead and implement it?

content.raw:
I think this list is never cleared on refresh, so it keeps growing. For example, if I press "New grid" four times I see the size of `grids` grow according to:

* On open: size[0]
* Press 1: size [1]
* Press 2: size[3]
* Press 3: size[6]
* Press 4: size[10]
content.html:
I think this list is never cleared on refresh, so it keeps growing. For example, if I press "New grid" four times I see the size of grids grow according to:

  • On open: size[0]
  • Press 1: size [1]
  • Press 2: size[3]
  • Press 3: size[6]
  • Press 4: size[10]
